Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) determination
Evidence_Type: Evidence of violence against new arrivals in Abuja
Legal_Provision: Section 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution by MEND in Nigeria
Evaluation_Standard: Reasonableness for relocation conditions, Correctness for risk of persecution
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of a viable Internal Flight Alternative (IFA)
Proceeding_Type: Refugee protection claim and subsequent judicial review
Application_Error: Failure to address evidence of violence against new arrivals in Abuja
Review_Outcome: Board's decision set aside and remanded for reconsideration
Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of violence and danger faced by new arrivals in Abuja
Legal_Standard: Two-part IFA test: (1) no serious possibility of persecution; (2) reasonable conditions for relocation
Application_Factor: Mobility rights and lack of family ties in Abuja
Decision_Outcome: Initial dismissal of refugee claim based on alleged viable IFA in Abuja
Decision_Review_Issue: Whether the Boardâ€™s IFA analysis was legally sound and reasonable
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for second branch of IFA, Correctness for first branch
Governing_Rule_or_Provision: Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) test under Canadian refugee law
Outcome_of_Review: Decision overturned due to unreasonable conclusion
Cause_of_Refusal: Perceived viability of Abuja as an IFA despite safety concerns
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to consider contradictory evidence on safety in Abuja
Procedural_Fairness: Deficient consideration of relevant evidence affecting fairness
Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Challenge to reasonableness of Board's interpretation and application of IFA test
Jurisdictional_Focus: Canada - Federal immigration and refugee law
Relevant_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, International Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Procedural_Issue: Incomplete factual basis in decision-making process
